writing_prompt: After years of estrangement, you reconnect with an old friend whose charm once lit up every room—but buried in your shared history is a betrayal you’ve never fully confronted.
story:
The door to the café swung open, and my father walked in, a familiar smile spreading across his face. I followed close behind, my eyes scanning the room for any sign of him. We hadn't seen each other in years, not since... well, not since everything fell apart. But as I spotted him, already sipping on a cup of coffee and chatting with the waitress, a mix of emotions swirled inside me. Nostalgia, guilt, and a dash of wariness. He looked older, of course, but that spark in his eyes was still there, the one that used to light up every room we entered.

As we made our way to the booth, he waved me over, his long strides eating up the distance between us. I slid in beside him, feeling a little awkward in my new jeans and T-shirt, while he looked like he'd just stepped out of a country club. He ordered me a cup of coffee, his eyes never leaving mine, and I couldn't help but notice the way he smiled at me, like we were old friends meeting for the first time in years.

The waitress, a woman with a kind face and a messy bun, set our cups down in front of us and left us to our reunion. My father took a sip of his coffee, his eyes crinkling at the corners as he savored the flavor. "You know, I was just thinking about the old days the other day," he said, his voice low and smooth. "Remember when we used to sneak into the movies on Fridays?"

I laughed, a little too loudly, and he chuckled along with me. We spent the next hour reminiscing about old times, sharing stories about our lives since we'd last seen each other. He'd gotten married, had two kids, and become a successful lawyer. I'd gone back to school, started working as a writer, and... well, I'd never really found my footing. But as we talked, I couldn't shake the feeling that there was something beneath the surface, something he wasn't telling me.

We ordered lunch, and as we waited for our food to arrive, the conversation turned to our shared past. He mentioned a party we'd thrown in college, one that had gotten out of hand and ended with us getting kicked out of the dorm. I laughed, remembering the chaos and the thrill of it all. But as we talked, I started to feel a twinge of unease. He was glossing over something, I was sure of it.

"Hey, remember that time we got into trouble with Alex?" he asked, his eyes sparkling with mischief.

I felt a pang of discomfort. Alex was a mutual friend, one who'd been hurt by my father's actions, and I'd never forgiven him for it. "Yeah, I remember," I said, trying to sound casual.

My father leaned in, his voice dropping to a whisper. "Come on, let's not rehash the past. We can just enjoy each other's company for once."

I hesitated, unsure of how to respond. Part of me wanted to let it go, to move forward and enjoy our time together. But another part of me couldn't shake the feeling that he was hiding something, that there was more to the story than he was letting on.

As we finished our lunch and prepared to leave, I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease. We'd had a good time, but I knew that our reunion was only the beginning. We'd have to face the past eventually, and I wasn't sure if I was ready.

As we walked out of the café, the sun beating down on us, I spotted a familiar figure across the street. It was Alex, the same Alex my father had hurt all those years ago. He looked older, too, but his eyes still held a deep sadness. I felt a pang of guilt, knowing that I'd never really confronted my father about what had happened.

My father followed my gaze, and for a moment, I thought I saw a flicker of recognition in his eyes. But then he smiled, and it was like nothing had ever happened. "Hey, let's grab some ice cream," he said, his voice light and carefree. "I want to hear more about your writing."

I hesitated, unsure of what to do. Part of me wanted to confront him about the past, to finally get some answers. But another part of me was scared, scared of what I might find out, scared of losing the connection we'd reestablished.

As we walked across the street, Alex's eyes locked onto mine, and I felt a surge of emotion. I knew that our reunion was only the beginning, that we'd have to face the past eventually. But for now, I just smiled and nodded, trying to push aside the doubts that were swirling inside me.

We grabbed ice cream and walked to the park, the sun beating down on us as we strolled along the path. My father talked about his kids, about his job, and I listened, feeling a sense of unease growing inside me. I knew that I couldn't keep avoiding the past forever, that eventually I'd have to confront my father about what had happened.

As we sat down on a bench, licking our ice cream cones, I felt a sense of nostalgia wash over me. We'd had good times, my father and I, times that I'd never forget. But as I looked at him, I knew that I couldn't ignore the past anymore. I had to confront it, to face the truth about what had happened.

"Hey, Dad," I said, my voice barely above a whisper.

He looked at me, his eyes sparkling with concern. "What's up, kiddo?"

I took a deep breath, feeling a sense of trepidation. "I need to talk to you about something," I said, my voice firm.

He nodded, his expression serious. "Okay, what is it?"

I hesitated, unsure of how to start. But as I looked at him, I knew that I couldn't keep it inside anymore. "It's about Alex," I said, my voice barely above a whisper.

My father's expression changed, just for a moment. I saw a flicker of guilt, of regret, before he smoothed out his face. "What about Alex?" he asked, his voice light and carefree.

I felt a surge of anger, of hurt. "You know what I'm talking about," I said, my voice firm. "You hurt him, Dad. You hurt him badly."

My father's expression changed, just for a moment. I saw a flicker of fear, of uncertainty, before he smiled again. "I don't know what you're talking about," he said, his voice light and dismissive.

I felt a surge of frustration, of anger. "Don't lie to me, Dad," I said, my voice firm. "I know what happened. And I want to know why."

My father's expression changed, just for a moment. I saw a flicker of sadness, of regret, before he looked away. "I don't know what to say," he said, his voice barely above a whisper.

I felt a sense of unease, of discomfort. I knew that I'd finally gotten him to admit the truth, but I wasn't sure if I was ready to hear it. "Tell me," I said, my voice firm.

My father took a deep breath, his eyes locking onto mine. "I'm sorry, kiddo," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "I'm so sorry."

I felt a surge of emotion, of hurt. I'd waited so long for him to admit the truth, to take responsibility for his actions. But as I looked at him, I knew that it wasn't enough. I needed more, needed to know why he'd done what he'd done.

"Why, Dad?" I asked, my voice firm.

My father's expression changed, just for a moment. I saw a flicker of guilt, of regret, before he looked away. "I don't know," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "I just didn't think about it, I guess."

I felt a surge of anger, of hurt. "You just didn't think about it?" I repeated, my voice firm. "You hurt Alex, Dad. You hurt him badly. And you just didn't think about it?"

My father's expression changed, just for a moment. I saw a flicker of fear, of uncertainty, before he looked away. "I'm sorry, kiddo," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "I'm so sorry."

I felt a sense of unease, of discomfort. I knew that our reunion was only the beginning, that we'd have to face the past eventually. But as I looked at my father, I knew that I couldn't let it go. I needed to know the truth, needed to understand why he'd done what he'd done.

As we sat there in silence, the sun beating down on us, I knew that our reunion was only the beginning. We'd have to face the past eventually, and I wasn't sure if I was ready.

writing_prompt: In 1970s Times Square, you work in a tiny cigarette booth surrounded by impatient hands and the haze of tobacco, dreaming of something more. One day, an unusual job interview promises escape—but at what cost?
story:
I take a long drag on my Lucky Strike, the menthol calming my frayed nerves as I watch the crowds jostle past the cigarette booth. It's another sweltering summer day in Times Square, the smell of stale air and exhaust fumes hanging heavy over the sidewalks. I've worked this booth for three years now, and it's a miracle I still have my sanity.

A middle-aged woman, her face a map of wrinkles, pushes her way to the front of the line. "I want a pack of Marlboros, but I need a coupon," she says, her voice like a rusty gate.

I nod sympathetically, handing her the coupon book. "Here you go, ma'am. That'll be $2.50."

She rummages through her purse, producing a crumpled dollar bill and a handful of coins. As I make change, a tall, lanky guy in a leather jacket sidles up to the booth. "Hey, kid, can I get a pack of Reds?" he asks, his voice like a lazy drawl.

I hand him the pack, and he tosses a $5 bill on the counter. "Keep the change, man," he says with a grin, and I watch as he saunters off into the crowd.

The woman pays and takes her cigarettes, giving me a nod of approval. "You're a nice kid. You should be a manager someday."

I smile, feeling a twinge of ambition. Maybe someday I'll make it out of this booth, leave this smoky haze behind.

Just then, a sleek, black sedan pulls up to the curb, and a suited man gets out. He's dressed to the nines, his tie perfectly knotted, and he looks like he just stepped out of a high-rise office building. He scans the area, his eyes locking onto me, and he strides over to the booth.

"Hi there," he says, flashing a bright smile. "I'm here for a job interview."

I raise an eyebrow. "Job interview? You must be joking."

The man chuckles. "Not at all. I'm looking for someone to manage a new project, and I think you'd be perfect for the job."

I snort. "A job? In Times Square? What kind of project could possibly pay enough to get me out of this booth?"

The man leans in, his voice taking on a conspiratorial tone. "Let's just say it's a... unique opportunity. You'll be working with a team of artists, musicians, and writers to create something truly innovative."

I raise an eyebrow. "Sounds like a bunch of hippies to me."

The man laughs. "Ah, but that's the beauty of it. We're not just talking about any old project. We're talking about a multimedia experience that will blow the lid off this city. And you, my friend, are the perfect person to help us make it happen."

I'm skeptical, but a spark of curiosity ignites within me. What could this project possibly be? And why does this guy think I'm the right person for the job?

The man hands me a business card. "Meet me at the Empire State Building at 5 PM tomorrow. Come alone."

I take the card, feeling a thrill of excitement. Maybe, just maybe, this is the break I've been waiting for.

As the day wears on, the crowds grow thicker, and the cigarette booth becomes a madhouse. I'm juggling multiple customers at once, my hands moving on autopilot as I hand out cigarettes and make change. But my mind is elsewhere, racing with possibilities and doubts.

What if this project is a scam? What if I get stuck in some kind of weird, avant-garde trap?

But what if it's the real deal? What if I finally get the chance to break free from this booth and do something meaningful?

As the sun sets over the city, casting a golden glow over the neon lights of Times Square, I make a decision. I'll take the risk. I'll meet this guy at the Empire State Building tomorrow and see where this wild ride takes me.

Little do I know, my life is about to take a drastic turn.
